had a question about getElementsByClassName case sensitivity; Specifically, I'm unconvinced that the case insensitive matching quirk shouldn't apply to it, for two reasons. The main one is that it seems really confusing to authors to have a situation where you attempt to match the exact same class(es) using two different methods, and get different results
the secondary not-actually-a-good-reason reason is that it's a lot harder for me to implement it inconsistently without a slight performance regression ;)
I've spoken with Hixie and sayrer (the moz implementer of it) and neither of them cares one way or the other, so I was curious what you thought
i guess i'm ok with it, if everyone is changing
is that a "don't care" or a "reluctant but willing"? If it's the latter, what's the reasoning? just avoidance of new quirks?
yeah, more if/else is annoying
although I know that in case of (at least) WebKit it's the reverse, so...
I'm actually surprised it's more if/else elsewhere as well
it seems like if the matching code is shared, in general the if would be as well
has only seen the WebKit patch
so maybe it's not such a big deal
keeping the case-insensitive quirk for all APIs that interact with classes makes sense to me. hmm, i wonder how svg's class="" works in quirks mode
zcorpan: hm, good question :)
brb, switching to wireless
quirks mode affects SVG too
in Safari 3 and Opera 9.5 at least
http://simon.html5.org/test/svg/quirks/001.htm
also firefox
smacks his head reading RFC2616
gsnedders: You should look where you're going instead of reading RFCs while walking, and then you'd be less likely to bash yourself on low-hanging obstacles
Philip`: or just try and make myself shorter
That would work too, unless you become short enough that you keep hitting the undersides of tables
Philip`: well, just make me even shorter
oh, wait, the undersides of doors…
hmm…
Hixie: ping
can anyone recommend an easy to use svn client for OSX?
resists the temptation to say the CLI client :P
(honestly, having spent a year or so using various GUIs, I concluded the CLI was by far the best)
CLI = command line interface?
yeah
I'll have to learn how to use it properly
If you're into TextMate - it has a svn bundle which is (imo) "ok"
is tempted to say "Don't use OS X"
is tempted to say "lol"
but yeah, I'd go with the command line client
'svn help' is a good place to start
(I'd go with the command line client on any POSIX OS)
gsnedders: well, for most of my Ubuntu use, I've found both esvn and rapidsvn to be good
virtuelv: I don't really like either :P
There's KDESvn too
which seems quite like TortoiseSVN, though less good
TortoiseSVN is awesome. That's what I use on windows
one option is that I just run TortoiseSVN on Windows using VMWare on my mac
though it might not be such a bad idea to learn the command line client
You could use Mercurial instead of SVN, and then you wouldn't be tempted by all these fancy graphical tools
gsnedders: pong
Hixie: see what I said yesterday about Content-Type, or should I repeat it?
yeah, Mercurial > SVN
Lachy: The command line is basically "svn up", "svn diff | less", "svn commit", so it's not that hard :-)
gsnedders: hmm
Philip`: sometimes you don't have a choice of VCS
http://krijnhoetmer.nl/irc-logs/whatwg/20071202#l-202
gsnedders: yeah i saw the question, was just thinking about it
Hixie: just for anyone else interested, more than anything, I thought that was what the hmm was :)

gsnedders: i would say that on the long run it is something we'd want to in the http spec, but that on the short run on a purely pragmatic basis we probably want it in the html5 spec for now, since it'll get more review that way
sighs at the irony: to reverse engineer error handling needed for HTTP an HTTP implementation is needed :\
It's hard to reverse engineer something without an implementation :)
That's true.
When you don't have an implementation but need one, that's just engineering

Now, a dilemma: IIS is "quite strict" because of earlier security holes, but other servers aren't; clients aren't strict at all — do I use the same code-path for both requests and responses which isn't strict and risk IIS never implementing it?
Or do I add a second code-path for requests that is more strict?
Hixie: maybe I'll merge it in after -00 is published
By "risk", I assume you mean "increase the already-significant risk of"?
Philip`: I got the impression that if it doesn't make it more lax (or, possibly slightly moreso than currently), they probably would
gsnedders: Ah, okay, that sounds reasonable
(But that's purely my impression from private discussions, so it may be totally wrong :P)
Part of me wants to only have one code-path as that will reduce the attack area, but knowing that it won't ever be used by IIS is big issue with that.
It's also less work for me, which is always nice
so I gave a presentation on HTML5 to a handful of interested people
among the feedback I got:
HTML5 is already a couple of years late considering competition from Flash and Silverlight
and
concern about the W3C having dropped the development of browser-relevant stuff (except CSS) for quite a while
yup, that's why we started
I've tried the svn command line, but when I try "svn commit", this is the error I get:
svn: Commit failed (details follow):
svn: Could not use external editor to fetch log message; consider setting the $SVN_EDITOR environment variable or using the --message (-m) or --file (-F) options
svn: None of the environment variables SVN_EDITOR, VISUAL or EDITOR is set, and no 'editor-cmd' run-time configuration option was found
because the w3c wasn't doing anything and we saw that we were getting competition and we had to response
hsivonen: Were they already concerned, or were they unaware of problems and only became concerned because of your presentation?
Philip`: unclear
Lachy: It's lucky that the error message tells you several ways to solve the error yourself ;-)
Philip`: I got a feeling that the audience didn't have a precise idea about the events that have lead to HTML5
how do I set the $SVN_EDITOR environment variable and what do I set it to?
Lachy: just use the -m parameter
Philip`: but I also got the impression that people had observed spec stagnation on their own
hsivonen: get them to speak to the "html4 is fine, why are we changing it" camp
and the "html4 was big enough, we should dump the new parts of html5 (like parsing)" camp
Hixie, thanks
Lachy: Hmm, I can't remember how you set it on OS X, but it's probably via some command in a ~/.bashrc or something
(I can't remember how you do it on Linux either)
-m worked

Lachy: I like having the external editor thing so it can show what files it's going to check in, and I can stop it if it's doing something stupid, but it's easy to revert mistakes so that's probably just me being unnecessarily fussy :-)
that's what 'svn diff' is for
i always diff before committing
Lachy: presumably export SVN_EDITOR=emacs or something would work, no?
Hixie: That introduces a race condition - my other self might change some files in the meantime and I wouldn't notice
jgraham_: s/emacs/vim/
oh and most of the questions I got were about video codec patent licensing, MPEG-LA and codec pluggability in upcoming browsers
jgraham: yeah, and s/emacs/nano/ :)
nano?!
nano.
nano is awesame
for small edits
jgraham_: GNU pico
totally awesame.
I like how Gentoo encourages nano by default
but emacs is what one has to use for real work
I guess for this kind of thing nano is actually quite sensible
for small edits, mg is pretty nice, since it's so similar to emacs
since it's actually reasonably easy to use
Philip`: i actually have that problem with the html5 spec, because the spec generation takes so long that i edit the spec before it's done (and before i see the diff to commit)
hsivonen: GNU pico? doesn't exist…
hsivonen: GNU nano is a pico clone
gsnedders: nano is the GNU approximation of pico
that's what he meant
meh.
not clear.
Not a very good approximation - they were off by three orders of magnitude
Philip`: which is what confused me so much.
has accidentally started an editor war

Philip`: i worked around that by working on a different file, which is copied over to my working copy when i generate the spec, so that even if i do edit the spec, the file that's diffed is the one i commit :_)
gsnedders: I thought jgraham_ was asking what nano was
has trouble telling apart rhetorical and actual question marks at this hour
bed time
nn
nn
Hixie: what does the generation actually do?
waves to hsivonen
gsnedders: cross-refs and section numbering, mostly
gsnedders: also, sticking on the header
ah
anyone have any thoughts about using two code paths instead of one for HTTP request/response parsing?

gsnedders: Would that be written as two separate versions of the parser, or would it work as one with "If (some condition), this is an error. Do (something crazy for legacy compatibility)" and a global "If you are a strict parser, stop at the first error"?
Philip`: for the tokeniser, the latter. For the actual parsing of header values, it would need to be two totally different algorithms.
(actually, for the parsing of header values, I could probably get away with, "There is an error if any header/value pair doesn't match its [RFC 2616] definition, with the following exceptions: …")
so it probably is doable without _too_ much extra text
wonders why Thunderbird is complaining that cpop.corp.google.com's certificate expired two years ago

Also, seeming IIS gets away with using a strict parser, it would probably with worth saying that, "It is RECOMMENDED that requests are parsed with a strict parser, and that responses are parsed with a weak/lax(?) parser."
wonders how Philip`'s computer can even get to a cert on cpop.corp.google.com
wonders whether weak or lax would be better
gsnedders: "liberal"?
or follow RFC 3986's example of "non-strict" :)
(which means I only need to name one)
Hixie: I have no idea, but I'm just downloading from pop.googlemail.com like normal, so it must be someone else's fault :-)

applies a SEP field around Gmail
